title: Police chief open to placing officers on city buses
text:
The city's police chief says he's open to the idea of police riding Winnipeg transit buses to keep drivers and passengers safe.
"I'm open to considering anything that will enhance public safety," Police Chief Devon Clunis said Friday.
"If that's part of it, I am willing to look at it."
Clunis said he'll first need to see reports and cost estimates, but said implementing policies to put plainclothes officers on some bus routes wouldn't be difficult for the police service.
No decision on the idea has been made; it will be discussed at the next meeting of the police board's strategic planning steering committee.
Amalgamated Transit Union president John Callahan told the police board Friday he believes a pilot project could begin with little to no cost to the Winnipeg Police Service.
He said the transit union has had talks with the police union to work out cost details.
There have been 45 assaults on Winnipeg Transit drivers this year, compared with 39 last year.
"Nobody wants to be a police state, but at the same time, there's been a free-for-all for a while now. It's time to take the necessary steps to ensure people's safety."
Callahan said he'd like to see Winnipeg adopt a program similar to one in Staten Island, New York, where undercover police ride buses and also keep an eye out for distracted drivers and street crime.
The proposal was discussed at this morning's police board meeting with full support from St. Boniface councillor Matt Allard and Daniel McIntyre councillor Cindy Gilroy, who said the plan could go a long way toward helping women, in particular, feel safe taking transit.
As part of the U.N. Safe Cities iinitiative, Gilroy said she's spoken to groups of women who fear waiting at bus stops at night, being attacked on buses or being followed home from their stop.
"They really go out of their way to make sure that they're going on specific routes, or they think twice before taking transit more than, say, men," Gilroy said. "I think having police on the buses will just add that level of security that women need to feel confident about taking our public transportation."
Police Board chairman councillor Scott Gillingham said if the police board's strategic planning steering committee supports the plan, the board will ask the police service to conduct a review of how the program would work.
"If it was the will of the committee to take it that far, to ask the service to do a review, I would not be opposed to that," he said.
When the city's transit bylaw was introduced last year, there were discussions about having cadets ride buses, but the plan didn't go ahead.
